H0.text: Evaporate sooner is what happens to liquid 1, which has a higher specific heat than liquid 2, when a student heats equal amounts of both liquids from room temperature over Bunsen burners.

H1.text: Take longer to increase in temperature is what liquid 1 will do when a student heats the same amount of two different liquids over Bunsen burners from room temperature, because liquid 1 has a higher specific heat than liquid 2.

H2.text: Condense over a longer period is what liquid 1 will do when it is heated from room temperature with a Bunsen burner, because it has a higher specific heat than liquid 2.

H3.text: Chemically breaking down at a faster rate is what liquid 1 will do if it has a higher specific heat than liquid 2 when a student heats the same amount of two different liquids over Bunsen burners, each starting at room temperature.

A4.text: If equal masses of 100 °F water and 150 °F mercury are mixed, the water temperature increases by 20 ° and the mercury temperature decreases by 30 ° (both arriving at 120 °F), even though the heat gained by the water and lost by the mercury is the same.

A5.text: The specific heat capacity of a substance is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a given mass by a certain amount, which directly determines how quickly a liquid's temperature increases when heated.
